title: Talking to Your Partner About HIV

content: You can’t understand how much of a learning experience it is to live with HIV until you’re faced with initiating some of the most difficult and uncomfortable conversations possible.
When talking about life with HIV, some experiences are more difficult than others. At the top of that list is becoming more comfortable disclosing your status. That’s always a personal choice.

It’s completely up to you to decide how, when, or even if you disclose your status. When the time comes, it’s not without risks. This is especially true when it comes to dating, sex, and relationships.

For most of us living with HIV, there’s a level of comfort to be attained before we can begin to wrap our minds around involving others. Because so much of what we deal with affects our sense of value, self-worth, desirability and confidence, it’s extremely important you feel ready to take all of this on.
Keep in mind it’s a lot to manage.

content: Having conversations about sex in general isn’t always easy. When you factor in HIV, it’s more complicated.

But as long as you and your partner are willing to lean into the unfamiliar and uncomfortable – asking questions and being honest about fears, expectations, desires, etc. – it’s absolutely possible to have a good outcome.

About 4 years after my diagnosis, I gained the courage to try again when it came to dating. I’d done an ample amount of disclosing my status to friends and family and to the public through my artistic work and advocacy.

Each time I met someone, I was forthright about HIV status. My thinking was: If someone wasn’t comfortable with me being HIV positive, it was best for me to know early on and not waste my time or theirs. This approach proved useful. There were men who, despite mutual interest and attraction, weren’t the right fit for me because of my status.
I met others who were completely OK with my status. I learned some valuable lessons from these experiences.

content: Although I went into those early dating encounters feeling insecure and concerned about being rejected, I found that the more transparent I was about my status, the stronger and more confident I became. This allowed me to form valuable bonds and connections with other black, gay, HIV-positive men going through the same things.

But above all, each time I met someone and disclosed my status, I felt less concerned about whether or not they were OK with it.  Without realizing it, I developed mental and emotional armor that boosted my confidence and security.

Talking to your partners about your HIV status is risky and difficult. It might feel downright impossible. Everyone’s experiences vary. But having these dialogues and putting yourself “back out there” is possible. In fact, the more often you do it, the more you’ll normalize having healthy conversations in  ways that empower you.
This allows you to be transparent while creating a safe space to talk about sex, dating, HIV prevention, and mutual enjoyment.
